responses: Preeclampsia is a serious pregnancy complication characterized by high blood pressure and signs of damage to other organ systems, typically after the 20th week of pregnancy. Symptoms of preeclampsia may include: High blood pressure (hypertension), Swelling of the hands, face, or legs, particularly sudden and severe swelling, Rapid weight gain, Severe headaches, Changes in vision, such as blurred vision or seeing flashing lights, Upper abdominal pain, usually under the ribs on the right side, Nausea or vomiting, particularly in the second half of pregnancy

Preeclampsia is a significant pregnancy complication that commonly develops after the 20th week of pregnancy and is characterized by elevated blood pressure and symptoms of various organ system abnormalities. Preeclampsia symptoms can include: hypertension, high blood pressure Hand, face, or leg swelling, especially if it is sudden and severe, gain weight quickly, painful headaches, visual changes, such as hazy vision or the perception of flashing lights, Upper abdominal pain, typically on the right side under the ribs, Especially during the second half of pregnancy, nausea or vomiting

High blood pressure and indications of damage to other organ systems characterize preeclampsia, a serious pregnancy condition that normally develops after the 20th week of pregnancy. Preeclampsia signs and symptoms could include: Hypertension is a term for high blood pressure. Usually occurring after the 20th week of pregnancy, preeclampsia is a dangerous pregnancy complication marked by elevated blood pressure and indications of harm to other organ systems. Preeclampsia symptoms might consist of: hypertension, a high blood pressure condition swelling of the hands, face, or legs, especially if it occurs suddenly and is severe, quickly gaining weight, significant headaches, alterations to vision, such as blurred vision or the perception of flashing lights, Usually under the right ribcage, upper abdominal ache nausea or vomiting, especially in the second trimester of pregnancy

responses: Pregnant women are at a higher risk of developing bladder or kidney infections compared to non-pregnant individuals. Hormonal changes during pregnancy can affect the urinary system, making it more susceptible to infections. Additionally, the growing uterus can compress the urinary tract, impairing urine flow and increasing the risk of bacterial growth. Symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI) may include frequent urination, pain or burning during urination, cloudy or bloody urine, and pelvic pain. If left untreated, UTIs can progress to kidney infections, which can be more serious. It is important to seek medical attention promptly if you suspect a UTI, as appropriate treatment with antibiotics is necessary to prevent complications

Anemia occurs when the body does not have enough healthy red blood cells to carry sufficient oxygen to tissues and organs. It can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, shortness of breath, and pale skin. Iron deficiency anemia is the most common type during pregnancy. Prenatal care typically includes regular monitoring of hemoglobin levels to detect and address anemia. Treatment usually involves iron supplementation and dietary adjustments to ensure adequate iron intake. Your healthcare provider will guide you on the appropriate iron supplementation dosage and provide dietary recommendations to support the treatment of anemia during pregnancy

However, unlike genuine labor contractions, they typically don't get stronger or more frequent.cervical alterations As labor progresses, your cervix may start to dilate and thin (efface). Throughout pregnancy checks, your healthcare professional will keep an eye on these modifications.Bloody Show: During pregnancy, the mucus plug that plugs the cervix may come out as a pink or bloody discharge. Start with the First Day of Your Last Menstrual Period (LMP): Identify the date when your last menstrual period began. This is considered the first day of your pregnancy, even though conception typically occurs about two weeks later.Add 280 Days: Pregnancy is typically about 280 days or 40 weeks long. Add 280 days to the first day of your LMP to estimate your due date.For example, if the first day of your last menstrual period was January 1, you would add 280 days to get October 8. So, October 8 would be your estimated due date.Keep in mind that this is just an estimate and not all pregnancies last exactly 40 weeks. responses: The anatomy scan, also known as the mid-pregnancy ultrasound, is a comprehensive ultrasound typically performed between weeks 18 and 22 of pregnancy. Here's how you can prepare for it, Schedule: Confirm the appointment date and time with your healthcare provider or imaging center.Hydration: Drink plenty of water in the days leading up to the scan. This can help provide clearer images.Comfort: Wear comfortable clothing that's easy to remove or adjust, as you might need to expose your belly for the ultrasound.Bladder: You might be asked to have a full bladder for the scan, so follow any instructions provided by your healthcare provider.Questions: Write down any questions you have for the technician or doctor regarding the scan.During the anatomy scan, the ultrasound technician (sonographer) will carefully examine your baby's development and organs. They'll assess the baby's head, brain, spine, heart, limbs, kidneys, and more. The technician will also check the placenta, amniotic fluid levels, and your cervix. The gender of the baby might also be visible if you choose to know it.The scan is non-invasive and painless, usually lasting around 20-45 minutes. The technician will apply a gel to your belly and use a handheld device (transducer) to create images on a screen. They might take measurements and capture still images.After the scan, the images will be reviewed by a radiologist or doctor.

It's possible that they'll collect measurements and still pictures.A radiologist or medical professional will examine the images after the scan.
